Judge in Microsoft Trial Delays Ruling for U.S. Reply The federal judge in the Microsoft antitrust case unexpectedly agreed to delay his final ruling for about a week, giving the Justice Department time to reply to Microsoft's proposal to water down the government's breakup plan.

Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson had planned to issue his final ruling, widely expected to call for a breakup of the company, by today. But Justice Department officials asked whether they could reply to Microsoft's comments on the government's remedy proposal, which were filed on Wednesday. [Page C2.]

Big Nasdaq Gain Leads Broad Rally Technology stocks soared, lifting the Nasdaq composite index 181.59 points, or 5.3 percent, to 3,582.50. It was the index's seventh-best gain in percentage terms. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also rose sharply, up 28.21 points, or nearly 2 percent, to 1,448.81, while the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 129.97 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,652.20. [C10.]

Retail Sales Increased 4.3% in May Retail sales climbed 4.3 percent in May with consumers buying housewares, appliances and summer fashions, even as higher interest rates and gasoline prices threatened to crimp spending. Several department store companies met or topped forecasts. Sears, Roebuck said sales jumped 3.5 percent. Expectations ranged from 1 percent to 3 percent. Its shares rose 50 cents, to $37.4375. Sales at J. C. Penney stores rose 1.1 percent, beating projections for unchanged sales. [C21.]

In Online Auctions, Rings of Bidders A close analysis of eBay art auctions reveals that the flourishing cyberauction world faces a deeper and more intransigent problem than people who bid on their own items to drive up the price: the prospect of rings of shill bidders, acting as partners. [A1.]

Fashionmall.com to Buy Boo.com The remnants of Boo.com, the Web retailer that became insolvent last week when investors refused to give it more cash, were acquired by Fashionmall.com, a New York Internet company, for an undisclosed price. [C4.]

Alcan Wins Algroup With Higher Bid Alcan Aluminium of Canada agreed to buy Algroup of Switzerland after an influential Swiss shareholder group threw its support behind a sweetened deal worth $4.7 billion. [C4.]

Advertising That's All About Luck Advertisers and media magnates are celebrating the concept of good fortune with a lengthening list of products, publications and pitches centered on the word ''lucky,'' including a magazine named Lucky, a character called Mr. Lucky who promotes the Excite Web site and the venerable Lucky Strike cigarette brand, which is being reintroduced with a big advertising push that plays up the name. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C6.]

Prudential to Buy Stake in Kyoei Life The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the largest life insurer in the United States, has tentatively agreed to take a stake in the Kyoei Life Insurance, one of Japan's many faltering life insurers. [C4.]

Manufacturing Index Edges Lower The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its overall index of economic activity in the manufacturing economy fell 1.7 points, to 53.2 in May, the lowest reading since February 1999. A separate report showed that spending on construction projects fell 0.6 percent in April. [C2.]
